awd_titl_txt: Structures, Metamaterials, Scattering, and Inverse Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
The significance of this project is multifold. It studies the forces that cable networks under tension can support, and this should be important to civil engineering, in particular to bridge or building design. It studies the possible elastic responses of 3-d printed metamaterials, and this could be helpful in designing structure that guide acoustic and elastic waves, for controlling vibrations and potentially for cloaking against sonar. It opens the field of boundary field equalities, that generalizes the notion of conservation laws, and which can be used for benchmarking numerical algorithms for calculating the response of inhomogeneous bodies. It develops a new approach to scattering of electromagnetic and elastic waves off an inclusion, that can help one understand the extent to which an arbitrarily shaped inclusion can scatter the waves. It develops new bounds that can be useful for predicting the electromagnetic response of two-phase composites even if one does not know the detailed microstructure. This should help in the identification of the most energy-absorbing composites and nano-particles. It explores what novel responses can be achieved in metamaterials, through coupled effects of electrical current flow, interaction with magnetic fields, and vibrations. This may lead to new types of magnetic field sensors and to novel devices coupling deformation and magnetic effects. For biomedical, engineering and counterterrorism applications it is vitally important to know what is inside a body from non-invasive testing, and it is better if one can say things with near certainty. The project will provide new methods of obtaining precise lower and upper limits on the volume occupied by an inclusion in a body. This may have applications to determining the size of certain tumors, or voids in a body, or the porosity in an osteoporotic bone. It studies new classes of theoretical inhomogeneous bodies for which there is an exact solution for the field and this may be useful for benchmarking numerical algorithms, and for gaining insight into how fields can be manipulated in inhomogeneous bodies. Finally, it trains two postdocs in interdisciplinary research.

The project provides a cross-fertilization of ideas from the four areas of Structures, Metamaterials, Scattering, and Inverse Problems. Some of these ideas, developed in the theory of composites, will be applied for the first time to inverse problems where one seeks to determine what is inside a body from boundary measurements, and to scattering problems where one seeks to understand the range of possible scattering responses as the shape of the scatterer is varied. The work on boundary field equalities, that stems from the theory of exact relations in composites, seeks to explore generalizations of the classic conservation law that a field which is divergence-free inside a body has zero net flux through the surface. For bodies containing certain wide classes of inhomogeneous media these equalities provide exact identities that are satisfied by the Dirichlet to Neumann map, which plays a central role when one seeks to extract information about what is inside a body from boundary measurements. The work on elastic tensors of 3-d printed materials seeks to bring a close to the challenging question of what elastic tensors are possible in mixtures of one given material plus void. The proposal addresses the inverse problem of estimating the size of an inclusion in a body, through boundary measurements in the time (rather than frequency) domain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit includes that it resulted in 20 papers highlights being: the paper ''Near optimal pentamodes as a tool for guiding stress....'' showing how theoretically stress can be guided in an optimal way, around a region to shield an object from stress, or towards a region to concentrate stress there, while maintaining the stiffness of the structure as much as possible; the paper ''On the forces that cable webs under tension...'' proves that any cable web possibly with internal junctions, supporting under tension a set of forces at the terminal nodes, can be replaced by one with no internal junctions - thus cable webs with all terminal nodes connected pairwise, and having no internal nodes, are the networks under tension most robust to external loadings; the paper ''An extremal problem arising in the dynamics of two-phase materials... '' shows how to design the time dependent applied fields to reveal volume fraction or shape information of an inclusion in a body from viscoelastic measurements taken at a specific time; the paper ''Improved bounds on the complex effective dielectric constant of a two-phase composite material and structures that attain them'' essentially draws to a close the long standing, four decade old,  problem of what range the complex effective dielectric constant of an isotropic composite of two isotropic phases can take as the microgeometry varies over all configurations having prescribed volume fractions of the two phases - the complex dielectric constant governs the electromagnetic response to applied fields oscillating at fixed frequency and a new optimal bound on it is derived while new microgeometries are identified that attain, or almost attain the other existing bound.

Some of the broader impacts are as follows: the spectrum of operators is of wide interest, particularly in quantum mechanics and the paper ''A new route to finding bounds on the spectrum of many physical operators'' provides a novel method for extracting information about the spectrum associated with many physical operators; the paper ''Theory of the Hall effect in three-dimensional metamaterials'' should improve our understanding of the possible responses of Hall-effect materials - such materials are of considerable technological importance as they are widely used in magnetic field sensors and atmospheric turbulence detection amoung other things; the paper ''Exact relations for Green's functions in linear PDE and boundary field equalities: a generalization of conservation laws'' could have wide ranging scientific impact as Green's functions are fundamental to the study of linear partial differential equations - moreover, the ''boundary field equalities'' that generalize the notion of ''conservation laws'' give exact identities satisfied by the response of bodies containing certain wide classes of inhomogeneous media; the paper ''3D metamaterials'' provides an extensive review of the subject of metamaterials that has received enormous attention in the last 20 years - as such it will provide a valuable source of information and references to the many scientists working in this area (it already has been cited 630 times according to Google Scholar); the paper ''On the forces that cable webs under tension...'' could lead to novel, lighter and more earthquake- or terrorism-resistant architectures of suspension bridges and buildings, and provide novel ways of guiding stress to desired locations; the paper ''Improved bounds on the complex effective dielectric constant of a two-phase composite material and structures that attain them'' identifies the most energy-absorbing isotropic two-phase composites, not just for electromagnetism but also for acoustics and antiplane elasticity. The existing bounds are widely used, and one expects a similar impact with our tighter bounds; the paper ''An extremal problem arising in the dynamics of two-phase materials... '' has potential applications as diverse as finding the volume fraction of holes in swiss cheese, estimating the size of a breast cancer, to detecting and estimating the size of a void in a casting - it also potentially enables one to determine information about the shapes of inclusions in a body; the paper ''Some open problems in the theory of composites'' outlines some outstanding problems of varying difficulties- the paper should serve to spark the interest of mathematicians, hopefully especially junior mathematicians and already one problem has been addressed by Yury Grabovsky and another by Christian Kern. Additionally, the project also enabled the interdisciplinary training of two postdocs, Christian Kern (now training to be a scientific patent lawyer in Germany) and Ornella Mattei (now an Assistant Professor working at San Francisco State University). Also Aaron Welters, an assistant professor at Florida Institute of Technology, and Maxence Cassier, a junior CNRS researcher at the Fresnel Institute and former postdoc, have enhanced their mathematical knowledge through our collaborations, and through meeting our associates such as Mihai Putinar, a collaborator of Ornella Mattei and myself.
